metadata.title: Nanopore-based native RNA sequencing provides insights into

body_text.text: In the last decade, next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies 1 revolutionized the field of 54 microbiology 2 , which is not only reflected in the exponential increase in the number of fully 55 sequenced microbial genomes, but also in the detection of microbial diversity in many hitherto 56 inaccessible habitats based on metagenomics. Using transcriptomics, important advances were 57 also possible in the field of RNA biology 3,4 that shaped our understanding of the transcriptional 58 landscape 5,6 and RNA-mediated regulatory processes in prokaryotes 7 . RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) 59 technologies can be categorized according to their platform-dependent read lengths and necessity 60 of a reverse transcription and amplification steps, to generate cDNA 8 . Illumina sequencing yields 61

highly accurate yet short sequencing reads (commonly 100-300 bp). Hence, sequence information 62 is only available in a fragmented form, making full-length transcript-or isoform-detection a 63 challenging task 9,10 . Sequencing platforms developed by Pacific Bioscience (PacBio) and Oxford 64 Nanopore Technologies (ONT) solved this issue. Both sequencing methods are bona fide single-65 molecule sequencing techniques that allow sequencing of long DNAs or RNAs 11,12 . However, the 66 base detection differs significantly between the two methods. PacBio-sequencers rely on 67 fluorescence-based single-molecule detection that identifies bases based on the unique fluorescent 68 signal of each nucleotide during DNA synthesis by a dedicated polymerase 11 . In contrast, in an ONT 69 sequencer, the DNA or RNA molecule is pushed through a membrane-bound biological pore with 70 the aid of a motor protein that is attached to the pore protein called a nanopore (Fig. 1a) . A change 71 in current is caused by the translocation of the DNA or RNA strand through this nanopore, which 72 serves as a readout signal for the sequencing process. Due to the length of the nanopore (version 73 R9.4), a stretch of approximately five bases contributes to the current signal. Notably, only ONT 74 transcriptomes 19,21-23 and to detect RNA isoforms in eukaryotes 24, 25 . However, prokaryotic 82 transcriptomes have not been characterized on the genome-wide level by native RNA-seq 83 approaches so far as prokaryotic RNAs lack a poly(A) tail which is required to capture the RNA and 84 feed it into the nanopore. 85

Here, we present a native RNA sequencing study of bacterial and archaeal transcriptomes using 86 Nanopore technology. We employed an experimental workflow that includes the enzymatic 87 polyadenylation of prokaryotic RNA to make them amenable for ONT´s direct RNA sequencing kit. 88

We evaluated the accuracy and reliability of native RNA-seq in comparison to published Illumina-89 based sequencing studying prokaryotic transcriptomes of bacterial (E. coli) and archaeal 90 (Haloferax volcanii, Pyrococcus furiosus) model organisms [26] [27] [28] [29] [30] [31] . The transcriptomic analysis 91 included determination of transcript boundaries, providing, among others, insights into 92 termination mechanisms in archaea. We moreover demonstrate that the long RNA reads gathered 93 on the ONT platform allow reliable transcriptional unit assignment. Strikingly, we gained insights 94 into the so far poorly understood ribosomal RNA (rRNA) maturation pathway in archaea and 95 detected putative new rRNA processing intermediates. As RNA modifications are retained when 96 sequencing native RNAs, we explore rRNA modifications in prokaryotes. Notably, by expanding 97

As some bioinformatic tools depend on single-read files we first converted multi-read FAST5 files 185 from the MinKNOW output to single-read FAST5 files using the ont_fast5_api from Oxford 186 Nanopore (https://github.com/nanoporetech/ont_fast5_api). To prevent actual good-quality 187 reads from being discarded (this issue was reported previously 13,37 ), we included both failed and 188 passed read folders in the following steps of the analysis. Demultiplexing was done by poreplex 189 (version 0.4, https://github.com/hyeshik/poreplex) with the arguments --trim-adapter, --190 symlink-fast5, --basecall and --barcoding, to trim off adapter sequences in output FASTQ files, 191 basecall using albacore, create symbolic links to FAST5 files and sort the reads according to their 192 barcodes. However, to ensure consistency between non-multiplexed and multiplexed samples and 193 because of some major improvements in the current basecalling software (guppy), albacore files 194

were not used. Instead demultiplexed FAST5 reads and raw FAST5 reads from non-multiplexed 195 runs were locally basecalled using Guppy (Version 3.0.3) with --reverse_sequence, --hp_correct, --196 enable_trimming and --calib_detect turned on. After that, relevant information from the 197 sequencing_summary.txt file in the Guppy output was extracted to analyse properties of raw reads 198 (see Supplementary Fig. 2 39 and Pyrococcus furiosus 203 DSM3638 31 using minimap2 (Release 2.17-r941, https://github.com/lh3/minimap2) 40 . Output 204 alignments in the SAM format were generated with the recommended options for noisy Nanopore 205

Direct RNA-seq (-ax splice, -uf, -k14) and also with (1) -p set to 0.99, to return primary and 206 secondary mappings and (2) with --MD turned on, to include the MD tag for calculating mapping 207 identities. Alignment files were further converted to bam files, sorted and indexed using 208 SAMtools 41 . Strand-specific wig and bigwig files were finally created using bam2wig (Version 1.5, 209 https://github.com/MikeAxtell/bam2wig). To evaluate the alignments, we first calculated the 210 aligned read length by adding the number of M and I characters in the CIGAR string 13 The definition of transcriptional units (TU) and our strategy to detect and annotate them was 232 based on a recent study that re-defined the bioinformatical search for transcriptional units (TU) 29 . 233

The TU annotation was performed in a two-step process in the following way: First, TU clusters 234 were defined by collapsing all reads that overlap and fulfill certain criteria that are commented on 235 extensively in the available code for this study 236 (https://github.com/felixgrunberger/Native_RNAseq_Microbes). In short, reads were filtered out 237 that did not align protein-coding genes (CDS) or tRNAs, had a mapping identity below 80%, were 238 spliced, were shorter than 50% of the gene body and did not cover either the 5´ or the 3´ 239 untranslated region. The remaining overlapping reads were collapsed in a strand-specific manner 240 and merged. 241

Finally, the collapsed reads that represent the TU cluster, were split according to the coverage drop 242 at the 3´ region of a gene. This was achieved by calculating the sequencing depth in a window of 243 20 nt upstream and downstream of the corresponding TTS and applying a deliberately low 244 the author/funder. To address the 3´ coverage bias and the underrepresentation of reads 248 that map to the 5´end and also for the 12 missing nucleotides at the TSS in general, all reads starting 249 at least 20 nt downstream of the annotated gene start were included. To not exclude too many 250 reads, the position of TTS were predicted similarly, by also including reads that have end positions 251 starting from 20 nt upstream of a gene end (TSS table in Supplementary Table 3, TTS table in  252   Supplementary Table 4) . 253

body_text.text: For the analysis of prokaryotic promoter elements, the sequences from 58 bases to 11 bases 254 upstream of all uncorrected TSS that are starting a TU were extracted, to identify relevant motifs 255 using MEME with default options except for a custom background file, calculated from intergenic 256 sequences of the respective organism 45 . The analysis of terminator sequences was performed 257 comparably by extracting all TTS that are located at the end of a TU and searching for terminators 258 in a sequence window from -45 to +45 from the TTS using MEME and the custom background 259 model. Heatmap analysis of motif positioning was performed by importing MEME FASTA 260 information into R. Metaplots of the nucleotide enrichment analysis (compare 26,46 ) were calculated 261 by comparing the genomic sequences surrounding a TTS in a window from -45 to 45 to randomly 262 selected intergenic positions (subsampled, n = 10000). 263
The performance of two different approaches (Tombo vs. error and basecalling properties) for the 265 detection of modified bases was evaluated: 266

(1) We used Tombo (Version 1.5, https://nanoporetech.github.io/tombo) to identify modified 267 bases based on a comparison to a theoretical distribution (de novo model) and based on the 268 comparison to a reference data set (sample-compare model) 47 . Briefly, for Fig. 6a reads mapping 269 to 16S rRNA were preprocessed, resquiggled and the raw signal plotted at a specific genomic 270 coordinate using the respective plotting command (tombo plot genome_locations). In addition, the 271 probability of modified bases was calculated using the detect_modification de_novo command. For 272 The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is . https://doi.org/10.1101/2019.12.18.880849 doi: bioRxiv preprint created by sorting the reads mapping to the 16S rRNA based on the position of the read start 275 (before or after gene start), thereby dividing the data set in reads that belong to mature and 276 unprocessed 16S rRNAs. The two read sets were used as input for the sample-compare method. 277

The two different models (de novo and sample-compare using non-mature 16S reads as a reference 278 set) were applied to the complete 16S, base-modification-probabilities extracted from the tombo 279 output and plotted using a custom R script. 280
(2) For calculating the frequency of correct, deleted and wrong nucleotides at a genomic position 281 the function pileup from the Rsamtools package was used (https://rdrr.io/bioc/Rsamtools/). 282

Plots were generated using custom R scripts. The results were compared to known modification 283 sites in 16S rRNA for Escherichia coli 48 and also compared to the ONT reference data. 318 the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

Library preparation for Nanopore native RNA sequencing of bacterial and archaeal transcriptomes 320

We performed whole-genome native RNA sequencing using the Nanopore sequencing technology 321 (referred to as Nanopore native RNA sequencing in this work) that can be applied to any 322 prokaryotic organism. The key steps of the library preparation are shown in Fig. 1a : after 323 enzymatic polyadenylation, the RNA is reverse transcribed to increase sequencing throughput 324 (recommended by ONT) 16 . Subsequently, a motor protein is added that feeds the RNA into the 325 Nanopore. Following this workflow, native RNAs from prokaryotic organisms can be sequenced. 326

Depending on the necessary sequencing depth, the libraries were barcoded using poreplex 327 (https://github.com/hyeshik/poreplex), since this is not yet supported by the official kits and 328 protocols from Oxford Nanopore. To identify primary and processed sites in both mRNA and rRNA, 329
we partially digested 5´-monophosphorylated transcripts using the terminator exonuclease (TEX) 330 and compared them to non-treated samples (see Supplementary Fig. 1a ). In contrast to many 331

Illumina sequencing-based approaches that make use of a specialised library preparation design 332 to tackle a well-defined question 8 , we evaluated the potential of native RNA sequencing to analyse 333 multiple transcriptomic features simultaneously including the identification of cis-regulatory 334 elements that govern transcription, the analysis of operon structures and transcriptional 335 boundaries, rRNA processing and 16S rRNA modification patterns (see Supplementary Fig. 1b Table 1 ). Due to large differences in the composition 357 of the RNAs used to train the basecaller and the sequenced reads, that contain mostly ribosomal 358

RNAs known to harbor base modifications, the overall quality is lower than for the spike-in control 359 in every data set 54 . To prevent useful reads from being discarded, we decided to also include reads 360 that fall below the standard quality score threshold of 7 and continued with the mapping of the 361 reads to the reference genomes 13 . 362 363

An advantage of the long-read Nanopore sequencing technique is that native RNA strands can be 365 sequenced directly as near full-length transcripts 55 . This is also reflected in the sequenced data 366 sets as aligned lengths up to 7864 nt can be observed (see H. volcanii NOTEX sample with a median 367 read length of 1390 nt, Supplementary Fig. 3c ). The majority of reads from E. coli and H. volcanii 368 samples mapped to the 23S rRNA (Fig. 1b , see Supplementary Fig. 3a ). In general, the read identity 369 of CDS-mapping reads is higher than for rRNA mapping reads, but lower than the spike-in control 370 (see Supplementary Fig. 3b,c) . It is noteworthy, that a minimum aligned length of about 100 nt 371 appears in the data sets (see Supplementary Fig. 3d ) when using the native RNA sequencing 372 protocol and minimap2 as mapping tool 16,40,56 . Unaligned reads had a median read length of 191 373 nt, in contrast to 572 nt for aligned reads (all data sets combined) suggesting that short reads could 374 not be aligned properly. As small RNAs, CRIPSR-RNAs or tRNAs fall below this threshold, we 375 the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is . https://doi.org/10.1101/2019.12.18.880849 doi: bioRxiv preprint excluded these RNAs from further analysis. While short transcripts are a problem, longer RNAs are 376 sequenced without loss in quality (see Supplementary Fig. 3e ). As the raw read quality correlates 377 with the mapping identity of the reads, problems during sequencing can be live-monitored in 378

MinKNOW and the run can be canceled allowing the loading of a new library (see Supplementary 379 Nanopore native RNA-seq data must be corrected by 12 nucleotides (Fig. 2b ). It has been observed 405 previously that about 12 nt are missing at the 5'-end of the sequenced RNAs. This observation can 406 be explained by a lack of control of the RNA translocation speed after the motor protein falls off 407 the 5´ end of the RNA (see Supplementary Figure 6a ) 56,57 . Promoter analysis confirmed the 408 presence of well-known sequence motifs of bacterial and archaeal promoters 27,31,58 . This includes 409 the TATA-box and B-recognition element (BRE) characteristic for archaeal promoters and the -10 410 element in bacterial promoters (Fig. 2d) . The -35 element in E. coli has been previously shown to 411 be less enriched compared to the -10 site 5 , which might explain why this element cannot be 412 detected in the Nanopore data set. To analyse TSSs in more detail, we compared the 5´ UTR lengths 413 for all genes with predicted TSS in ONT and Illumina data sets (see Supplementary Figure 6b ,c,d). 414

The overall correlation between the two techniques was very high (see Supplementary Fig. 6 ). As 415 expected, the correlation improves with increasing sequencing depth for a gene (>5 reads). While 416 TEX-treatment is a common way of predicting TSS in Illumina sequencing, we observed that it is 417 not necessary for ONT data as very similar TSS are found in both TEX and NOTEX data sets (ρ = 418 0.86) (see Supplementary Figure 6e ). 419 420 Transcription termination sites 421 Native RNA reads are sequenced in the 3´ to 5´ direction, which is a major advantage in the 422 detection of termination sites as any bias introduced after polyadenylation can be excluded. 423

Currently, no reference data sets for the archaeal organisms were available, the distribution of 3´ 424 untranslated regions (3´UTRs) in E. coli ONT data closely resembles the data from a previous Term-425 seq study 26 . Untranslated regions at the 3´end of an annotated transcript are longer and more 426 uniformly distributed in E. coli than in the two archaeal species (Fig. 2c) As observed for E. coli termination sequences, Cytosines are enriched over Guanosine adjacent to 451 the TTS in P. furiosus (Fig. 2e) . Termination motifs detected in the E. coli data set cover both 452 intrinsic (poly(U)) and Rho-dependent termination signatures (see Supplementary Fig. 7a ,b) 26 . We 453 classified the stem-loop forming motif as Rho-dependent signatures, as these were not enriched in 454 the poly(U) terminated genes. However, the stem-loops could potentially also represent 455 processing or pause sites. 456 457

Long-read sequencing of native full-length RNAs has the potential to improve and facilitate 459 genome-wide transcriptional unit (TU) annotation, which can be visually explored in a genome 460 browser coverage track (Fig. 3a) . For whole-genome analysis, the annotation strategy was based 461 on two major observations: First, during RNA preparation, RNA processing or degradation can 462 the author/funder. The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is . https://doi.org/10.1101/2019.12.18.880849 doi: bioRxiv preprint occur, which limits the probability of sequencing an RNA in its native form as the percentage of 463 full-length transcripts decreases with expected gene size (see Supplementary Fig. 9a) . Secondly, 464

we detected a decrease in coverage from the 3´ to 5´end of the RNA in all RNA classes except for 465 the spike-in control (see Supplementary Fig. 9b ), which is a limitation reported in the 466 literature 13,60,61 . Therefore, we assume that not Nanopore sequencing but library preparation 467 causes this problem. Based on this information, we developed a strategy that first collapses all 468 overlapping reads and then splits them according to a significant coverage drop on the 3´ ends 469 (annotation of TUs based on this strategy in Supplementary Table 5) . We compared the results to 470 database annotations and found that most of the differences are either caused by the low 471 sequencing depth or by single-unit operons that have been collapsed and are now two-unit 472 operons in the ONT data sets (see Supplementary Fig. 10a,b) 29,50 . Even though limited read 473 availability is a concern in all data sets, many large operons were detected for all organisms (see 474 Supplementary Fig. 10c ). In case of limited bioinformatical resources, TUs can be explored visually 475 in a genome browser, which is mostly not possible for Illumina reads (Fig. 3 , see Supplementary 476 Fig. 11,12) . It further allows a quantitative analysis of individual transcripts in relation to other 477 elements of the TU and performs much better than pure bioinformatical prediction or molecular 478 biology methods (RT-PCR) as shown for the archaellum operon in P. furiosus (Fig. 3) seq data, the analysis shows that this operon is split into two transcription units. This shows that 484 the ONT native RNA sequencing method provides the opportunity to correctly annotate 485 transcriptional units thereby outperforming the bioinformatics-only prediction as well as the 486 visual inspection of Illumina coverage (see Supplementary Fig. 11) . Besides, we confirmed the 487 complex transcription pattern of the major ribosomal protein gene cluster in E. coli that stretches 488 over more than 10 kB, including the accurate determination of TSS and TTS and a putative cleavage 489 site in the secY gene (see Supplementary Fig. 12) 63 . 490 the author/funder. The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is . https://doi.org/10.1101/2019.12.18.880849 doi: bioRxiv preprint Detection and confirmation of rRNA processing in E. coli 491 Next, we aimed to analyse the multi-step rRNA processing pathway which is the major RNA 492 maturation pathway in any prokaryotic cell. We first focus on the E. coli data set as the processing 493 of bacterial rRNAs is well characterized 64-66 . Ribosomal RNA in E. coli is transcribed from 7 494 independent rDNA operons, containing the mature rRNAs (16S, 23S and 5S rRNAs) and some 495 tRNAs which are intersped by RNA spacers elements 67 . In agreement with a previous study, 496 transcription of rrnC from two promoters (transcription start sites at -293 and -175) was detected 497 accurately (Fig. 4a,b) 68 . 498
The rRNA maturation process, which requires the action of well-defined ribonuclease activities, 499 culminates by the formation of stoichiometric amounts of mature 16S, 23S, and 5S rRNAs 64-66 . 500

Unexpectedly, the sequencing efficiency of mature 16S rRNA was lower than the 23S rRNA (Fig.  501 4a). Moreover, although we could properly detect RNA of similar size or longer (see above), the 502 short-lived full rDNA operon transcript detected in RNase III deficient strain 69 , is not observed 503 using our experimental set-up. In contrast, the downstream pre-rRNAs which are generated by the 504 action of RNAse III were detected (Fig.4) . Among these intermediates, the 17S pre-rRNA with 115 505 additional nt at the 5´ end and 33 nt at the 3´ end of the 16S rRNA, was identified (Fig. 4b) . 506

Additional 16S rRNA processing sites (RNase E: -66, RNase G: 0 5´mature) are also detected ( Fig.  507   4 b,c) . Recent studies were suggesting that the 3´end of the mature 16S rRNA is generated by 3´-5´ 508 ribonucleases activity and/or endonucleolytic cleavage 70,71 . In addition to the mature 16S rRNA 509 3´end, we could observe reads of decreasing length spanning from +33 nt (RNaseIII) to 0 (related 510 to 16S rRNA 3´end), that could account for 3´-5´ exonuclease processing activity (or degradation 511 during sample preparation). Together we could accurately identify all the known processing sites 512 at nucleotide resolution in wildtype E. coli. 513 514 Insights into archaeal ribosomal RNA processing 515

In comparison to bacteria or eukaryotes, ribosomal RNA processing in archaea is still poorly 516 understood 70,72-74 . Our current knowledge suggests that the primary polycistronic rRNA precursor 517 contains processing stems formed by the 5´-leader and 3´-trailer sequences surrounding the 16S 518 and 23S rRNAs 72,73,75,76 . In Euryarchaeota, the 16S and 23S rRNAs are additionally separated by the 519 the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is . https://doi.org/10.1101/2019.12.18.880849 doi: bioRxiv preprint presence of an internal tRNA. In most archaea, the 16S and 23S rRNA processing stems contain a 520 bulge-helix-bulge motif which is, in the context of intron-containing tRNA, recognized by the 521 splicing endonuclease endA 75-77 . Similar to intron-containing tRNA maturation, processing at the 522 bulge-helix-bulge motifs results in the ligation of the resulting extremities, thereby generating the 523 archaeal specific circular pre-16S and circular pre-23S rRNAs 73,76,78,79 . The molecular mechanisms 524 by which the circular pre-rRNA intermediates are further processed into linear mature rRNA are 525 unknown 73,76 . 526

By analysing single reads, we aimed to confirm and expand our knowledge on the poorly 527 characterized multi-step ribosomal maturation process in P. furiosus and H. volcanii (Fig. 5a,b,c,  528 see Supplementary Fig. 13a,b) Supplementary Fig. 13c) . Surprisingly, 5´ and 3´end 532 positions did not precisely match the availablle annotations at NCBI 533 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome/) or the archaeal genome browser (AGB, 534 http://archaea.ucsc.edu). In contrast, these mature rRNA extremities did match our independent 535 experimental validations by primer extension analysis of the 5´ends of the 16S and 23S rRNAs of 536 H. volcanii (Supplementary Fig. 15f ). In addition, the majority of the expected processing sites, 537 notably at the predicted or known bulge-helix-bulge motifs 78 , were faithfully observed in P. 538 furiosus and H. volcanii (see Supplementary Fig. 14,15) . 539

Despite the high sequencing depth of the (pre-)rRNA, we did not detect a full-length precursor 540 consisting of the 16S leading-16S-tRNA-23S-23S trailing elements in P. furiosus and H. volcanii, 541 suggesting that early rRNA processing occurs rapidly in these cells. The remaining reads were 542 grouped according to their 5´ leading and 3´ trailing lengths into five additional categories that are 543 less abundant (with less than 1600 counts in each group): (1) a processing variant that entails the 544 16S rRNA leading/trailing sequence-tRNA-23S rRNA leading/trailing sequence, (2) probably 545 fragmented full-length precursor rRNAs, (3) 16S rRNA leading/trailing sequence-tRNA, (4) 16S 546 rRNA leading/trailing sequence-tRNA-23S rRNA and (5) tRNA-23S rRNA (Fig. 5 , see 547 Supplementary Fig. 13 ). The early 16S rRNA leading/trailing sequence-tRNA-23S rRNA trailing 548 sequence precursor (1) or 16S rRNA leading/trailing sequence (3) generated by cleavage and 549 the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is . https://doi.org/10.1101/2019.12.18.880849 doi: bioRxiv preprint reciprocal ligation of the pre-16S and pre-23S rRNAs at the predicted bulge-helix-bulge motifs 550 were detected very accurately, and are reminiscent of previous observations 76 (Fig. 5 , see 551 Supplementary Fig. 13d) . Given the number of reads, the direction of ONT sequencing from 3´ to 552 5´ and the accurate mapping, it is unlikely that the additional putative rRNA precursors (variants 553 4, 5) carrying the leading sequence in combination with 23S rRNA and tRNA-23S rRNA are all 554 arising from experimental artifact (Fig. 5a,b) (see also Discussion). This processing variation could 555 have been overlooked in the past in the analysed archaea, as these are only minor fractions of the 556 transcripts present in the cell or are specific to P. furiosus. Shortened 23S rRNA reads (variants 4, 557 5) and the overall visible 3´ to 5´ coverage drop can most likely be explained by fragmentation and 558 degradation during library preparation, secondary structures that prevent efficient loading into 559 the nanopore or truncation of RNA reads caused by physical artifacts that have been described 560 before and include problems during RNA translocation or disruptions of the ionic current 561 signal 13,52,56 . Furthermore, it cannot be excluded that non-mature reads are categorized as 562 fragmented reads and will be assigned as mature 16S or 23S rRNA. 563

Highly enriched positions that differ from the annotation of the mature rRNAs and cannot be 564 assigned to a processing site may represent a wrong annotation of the rRNA locus or currently 565 unknown processing sites in the two archaeal species 31,39 . To provide further examples that show 566 the potential to describe maturation and processing events for prokaryotic rRNA, we sequenced 567 an H. volcanii wildtype strain grown under low salt conditions (see Supplementary Fig. 15b,c) 28 . 568

Under these conditions, a 16S rRNA precursor with an extended 5´UTR (position -121 -5´bulge) 569 appears that is only enriched in this condition. Quantification by comparison with the NOTEX 570 wildtype set confirms the previous detection of this rRNA variant in a gel-electrophoretic analysis 571 of the rRNA (see Supplementary Fig. 15b) 28 . 572 573

More than 160 types of modified bases have been described in RNAs so far 48 . In contrast to other 575 sequencing techniques, Nanopore-based sequencing offers the possibility to detect base 576 modifications directly, as these modifications lead to an electric current signal that differs from the 577 expected theoretical distribution obtained by the unmodified nucleotides sequence 14,15,20,81 . body_text.text: Before expanding the analysis to the full-length mature rRNA, we focused on the dimethylation 580 was very high for the stretch of Guanosines adjacent to position 1450 (Fig. 6a) . Mapping to single-584 nucleotide resolution is difficult as more than one base contributes to the actual electric current 585 signal in the nanopore 83 . In the next step, a comparison of a wildtype sample to a deletion mutant 586 of KsgA confirmed the absence of the dimethylation in the deletion strain and confirmed that the 587 m 6 2A modifications and not the homopolymer-G-stretch are responsible for the altered current 588 signal (Fig. 6b) . The analysis further revealed a reduced signal variability at non-modified 589 positions between the two samples in comparison to the theoretical distribution, which leads to 590 less false positives in the statistical analysis. As the de novo model has a higher error rate 591 compared to the sample-compare model, we generated two read sets by sorting full-length 16S 592 rRNA transcripts according to their 5´ leading length to mature (n: 2744) and pre-rRNAs (n: 102) 593 in the Haloferax wildtype data set (Fig. 6c) . The calculated base modification probabilities and 594 electric current signal distributions for this model are very similar to the wildtype/∆ksgA set, 595

body_text.text: indicating that the two m 6 2A modifications were not quantitatively introduced in the pre-16S-596 rRNA reads (Fig. 6d) . This finding is in line with a proposed "quality control" function of KsgA 597 during late biogenesis of the small ribosomal subunit 84-86 and further highlights the potential to 598 detect the introduction of base modifications at a different stage of rRNA maturation. 599

body_text.text: Next, we applied the described de novo and sample-compare model to the full 16S rRNA of all three 600 organisms and compared the results to positions known from literature 48,49 . Applying a probability 601 threshold of 0.5, we found that 60% (de novo) and 1.89% (sample-compare, 28 bases) of the bases 602 in the 16S rRNA are modified in H. volcanii (Fig. 6e) , which emphasizes the better performance of 603 the sample-compare model by the vastly reduced number of false-positivly detected RNA 604 modifications. 10 of the 28 predicted bases (please note that approximately five bases contribute 605 to the signal in the nanopore and that a base single modification therefore influences the current 606 signal at the surrounding bases as well) can be assigned to known base modifications at positions 607 910, 1430 and 1450/1451 49 . Moreover, these data support the long-standing 610 hypothesis that hyperthermophilic organisms might stabilize their rRNAs by a higher degree of 611 RNA modifications 87,88 . 612
body_text.section: Towards mapping of RNA base modifications 574

body_text.text: It is noteworthy that the predicted large number of modifications lead to a loss in read quality. This 613 is for example seen when analysing the Pyrococcus data set, as the quality score is also based on 614 the comparison of detected to theoretical read signal (compare Supplementary Fig. 3c) . To look at 615 this observation in more detail, we compared the results from the raw squiggle Tombo approach 616 that is not dependent on mapping of the reads to the mapping properties of the reads. This 617 methodology is based on an approach that was recently used to identify m 6 A RNA modifications 618 from native RNA reads with an accuracy of ~90% 14 . After mapping, the frequency for the 619 respective nucleotide at every position in the 16S rRNA to be correct, wrong or deleted was 620 calculated. Homopolymer stretches in the RNA increase the likelihood that the correct number of 621 nucleotides is not correctly identified and this, in turn, leads to an increased number of deleted 622 nucleotides, which is also visible in the Haloferax data sets at the G-stretch adjacent to the m 6 2A 623 modifications ( Supplementary Fig, 16a,b) . The overall frequency of wrongly assigned and deleted 624 nucleotides was much higher in P. furiosus (16.4%) than in E. coli (10.7%) and H. volcanii (10.4%) 625 ( Supplementary Fig. 16c ). Interrogating the full-length 16S rRNA, we found that miscalled 626 positions are equally distributed among the whole transcript ( Supplementary Fig. 16d ,e,f). 627

body_text.text: Performing whole-genome native RNA-seq study in prokaryotes provided us with a wealth of 638 information on transcriptional and post-transcriptional processes in E. coli and the archaeal model 639 organisms H. volcanii and P. furiosus. Here, we will mostly discuss new biological insights that 640 emerged from our study. Additionally, we will reflect on the advantages and disadvantages of 641 Nanopore native RNA-seq. 642

Bacterial and archaeal transcription is an intensely studied molecular process and the mechanisms 644 of basal transcription are well understood 89 . Native RNA sequencing allowed us to retrieve 645 accurate information of transcript boundaries on both 5´ and 3´ ends. Our data show that 3' UTRs 646 length distributions are comparable between E. coli, P. furiosus and H. volcanii with the majority of 647 mRNAs showing a length between 30 -70 nt. Similar to bacteria, archaea encode large numbers of 648 small non-coding RNAs 90 . However, many regulatory events that involve the regulation via small 649

RNAs take place at bacterial 5' UTRs 91 . We and others found that 5' UTRs are significantly shorter 650 in archaea supporting the idea that post-transcriptional regulation is mediated via the 3' rather 651 than the 5' UTR in archaea 92 . Additionally, we determined transcription termination sites, which 652 are well analysed for bacterial species but only a few studies focused on archaeal termination 653 mechanisms, especially on the genome-wide level. In both archaeal species, poly(U) stretches were 654 overrepresented at termination sites agreeing well with termination sequences found in Sulfolobus 655 and Methanosarcina 46 . Interestingly, the majority of TTS found in Pyrococcus transcripts is 656 composed of two U-stretches with at least five consecutive uridine bases while a subclass of 657

Haloferax transcripts is almost exclusively terminated by a single U-stretch with four uridine 658 bases. It has been shown that a five base U-stretch is sufficient to induce termination in vitro 59,93,94 . 659

Similar observations were described in a recent study by Berkemer et al, which identified a 660 poly(U)4 stretch to be the termination signal in intergenic regions 95 . However, the current data set 661 suggests that this short termination signal might be a specific feature for a subclass of Haloferax 662 transcripts resembling the poly(U) termination motif found in E. coli. All other archaeal organisms 663 (P. furiosus, M. mazei, S. acidocaldarius) investigated so far terminate transcription at multiple 664 the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is . https://doi.org/10.1101/2019.12.18.880849 doi: bioRxiv preprint consecutive poly(U) stretches. Possibly, Haloferax relies on additional termination signals or yet 665 unknown termination factors. A putative candidate is archaeal CPSF1 (aCPSF1), a recently 666 described archaeal termination factor 96 that is widespread in archaea. aCPSF1 acts as ribonuclease 667 that cleaves transcripts after a poly(U) stretch to trim transcripts and facilitates transcription 668 termination in Methanococcus maripaludis. The arising 3' UTR isoforms were detected using Term-669 seq analysis 96 . We also observed heterogeneity in the case of the Pilin and Alba transcripts, 670 respectively, that are distinguished by varying lengths of the 3' UTR suggesting that aCPSF1 might 671 trim a subset of genes in H. volcanii and P. furiosus. It is noteworthy that 3' UTR isoforms were also 672 detected in Term-seq studies with Sulfolobus and Methanosarcina 46 . However, in contrast to the 673 Pilin and Alba transcripts, the 3' UTR isoforms arise from termination at different sites of a single 674 continues poly(U) stretch suggesting that the isoforms arise from a stochastic termination process 675 of the RNA polymerases at an extended poly(U) stretch at the end of the gene. Taken together, 676 these data demonstrate that a variety of termination mechanisms (that can even co-occur in the 677 same cell) can be found in archaea ranging from stochastic intrinsic termination at extended 678 poly(U) stretches (Pyrococcus, Sulfolobus, Methanosarcina), to abrupt termination at short uridine 679 tracts (H. volcanii) and factor-dependent termination that results in trimming of the 3'UTR (H. 680

In the context of transcription, the long and overlapping native RNA reads helped us to analyse the 682 transcriptional landscape at multigene operons. More specifically, we focused on the archaellum 683 operon as the transcription unit assignment remained ambiguous so far 62 . In contrast to 684 bioinformatical and Illumina RNA-seq-based predictions and attempts to unravel the TU via 685

primer extension experiments, we found that the archaellum operon in P. furiosus is transcribed 686 in multiple units with highly diverse abundances. The flaB0 gene encodes the major flagellin 687 protein that forms the filament of the archaellum and therefore, the organism has to produce this 688 protein in large quantities as apparent from the expression level 62 . Interestingly, FlaD is expressed 689 at comparably high levels as well as supporting the idea that FlaD is a major constituent of the 690 archaellum in P. furiosus. It has been speculated that FlaD forms the cytosolic ring of the archaellum 691 that anchors the filament in the outer membrane 97 . The identity and functional role of FlaD are, 692 however, not known so far. 693 the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

In this study, we have assessed the suitability of native RNA sequencing to obtain information on 696 the rRNA maturation pathway of different prokaryotes. Ribosomal RNA maturation proceeds via 697 the coordinated and defined order of ribonucleases action (exonucleolytic and/or endonucleolytic 698 cleavages) which generate pre-rRNA intermediates with defined premature rRNA 699 sequences 66,74,98,99 . The establishment of faithfull rRNA maturation maps in model organisms, like 700 E. coli, S. cerevisiae or human cell culture has required numerous analyses over the past decades 701 66,74,98,99 , and remains a technical challenge. Therefore, methodologies that might accelerate the 702 systematic analysis of rRNA maturation pathways across the tree of life, thereby enabling to 703 unravel the diversity of rRNA maturation strategies need to be established. Beyond the 704 identification of processing sites, the order of the processing events which can be, in part, deduced 705 from co-occurrence analysis of the 5´and 3´extremities is of biological relevance 66,74,98,99 . Whereas 706 we could confirm and extend our general view on the rRNA maturation pathway in archaea, the 707 3´-5´ processivity of Nanopore native RNA sequencing observed for rRNA impedes the accurate 708 analysis of pre-rRNA extremities co-segregation (see Fig. 5 and Supplementary Fig. 9b) . Sources for bias could emerge (i) from 381 the poly(A)-tailing efficiency that might differ between transcripts and (ii) from the loss of certain 382 transcripts during library preparation or sequencing problems. Comparing the initial amount of 383 RNA with the reverse transcribed DNA, we observed that the enzymatic addition of a 3´ poly(A)-384 tail is not very efficient (~10%). In general, the addition of poly(A)20 (length of the reverse 385 transcription adapter) is sufficient to allow for the annealing of the poly(T)-adapter required for 386 reverse transcription and sequencing. This goes in line with the shortest median length we 387 observed for the 5S rRNA (see E. coli TEX sample) (seeSupplementary Fig. 4). For most of the 388 transcripts, a tail with 50 to 100 nt was detected. FIGREF3.text: . The motif locations for both Haloferax and Pyrococcus ONT sets suggest that accurate TTS 436 detection of transcripts terminated by poly(U) stretches is currently not possible. We observed 437 that homopolymer sequences are removed during trimming of the reads, which leads to TTS 438 positions that are positioned upstream of the poly(U) signal. Analysing individual transcripts in H. 439 volcanii and P. furiosus, we found that a single transcript can exhibit diverse 3' ends. This is true 440 for the Pilin transcript in H. volcanii and the Alba transcript in P. furiosus, respectively 441 (Supplementary Fig. 8). Both genes are highly expressed and some transcripts carry extended 3' 442 UTRs. While the majority of transcripts are terminating at the first poly(U) stretch, a subset of 443 transcripts is substantially longer and terminates at a second poly(U) termination signal 444 (Supplementary Figure 8). Interestingly, homogeneous short poly(U) signals are found both at the 445 canonical termination site and the termination site of the elongated 3'UTR in the case of the Pilin 446 transcript in H. volcanii. In contrast, the Alba gene transcripts in P. furiosus are terminated at both 447 sites via long consecutive poly(U) stretches. Surveying the heterogeneity of the transcripts with an 448 extended 3'UTR, we found a heterogeneous distribution in the length of the transcripts, which 449 possibly indicates a step-wise trimming of the 3'UTR to yield the mature RNAs. 450

FIGREF6.text: 709 Nevertheless, we could confirm the presence of processing sites and pre-rRNA intermediates in 710 the different organisms analysed, with the exception of the archaea specific circular-pre-rRNA 711 intermediates 73,76,78,79 , which escape analysis due to the lack of 5´/3´ extremities. Among the 712 identified pre-rRNA intermediates, precursor (4) observed in P. furiosus, which include ligation at 713 the bhb motif of the upstream region of the 16S leader and downstream region of the 16S trailer 714 sequences continuous to the downstream tRNA/23S sequences is of particular interest. The 715 presence of this intermediate suggests that the 16S rRNA bulge-helix-bulge processing occurs 716 prior to internal tRNA and 23S rRNA maturation. This observation is also in agreement with our 717 recent cis-acting element analysis performed in H. volcanii 73,76,79 . In fact, based on this analysis we 718 have proposed a model by which 16S rRNA maturation proceeds and is required for the 719 downstream maturation of the internal tRNA and 23S rRNA. Moreover, we have hypothesized that 720 ligation of the 16S rRNA leader/trailer resulting from the 16S rRNA bulge-helix-bulge maturation 721 process generates a putative new pre-rRNA intermediate which we could observe for the first time 722 in Pyrococcus using native RNA sequencing. In addition, the presence of intermediates (1) and (relevance of the additionally identified intermediates for rRNA maturation is yet 727 unclear and will need to be appraised in the light of additional functional analysis. In conclusion, 728 despite some intrinsic limitations, direct RNA sequencing can be a useful tool to approach 729 intricated maturation pathway like rRNA maturation, and expand our understanding of RNA 730 maturation in prokaryotes. 731 732 Towards the mapping of rRNA modification patterns 733 RNA modifications have been described already in the 50-60s, and has gained significant attention 734 over the last years, under the generic term of epitranscriptome 100-102 . The high-throughput 735 analysis of these post-transcriptional modifications remains challenging and mostly relies on 736 indirect methods, like primer extension stops analysis or chemical recoding/derivation 737 strategies 103,104 . Native RNA sequencing may fill an important gap to systematically analyse RNA 738 modifications on a genome-wide scale. However, global strategies enabling the faithful 739 determination of RNA modification identity and position needs to be developed. Several recent 740 focused analyses have explored different strategies to evaluate the capacity of ONT to accurately 741 detect RNA modifications (e.g. m6A) 14,15,55,105,106 . In this study, we focused on the 16S rRNA which 742 is known to carry different types of RNA modifications which are introduced at different positions 743 and different stages of the small ribosomal subunit maturation 73,107 . Our study provides evidence 744 that RNA modification detection benefits of the use of unmodified/hypo-modified references (in 745 agreement with recent studies 15,106 ). In this study, we have used a sample-compare approach 746 analysing pre-rRNAs, which are expected to contain incomplete modification patterns, in 747 comparison to mature rRNAs, which are expected to harbor a completed modification pattern. To 748 validate our approach we have first focus on the almost universally conserved KsgA-dependent 749 dimethylations of the 16S rRNA 15,82,85 . Using our sample-compare strategy and KsgA deletion 750 strain we could unambiguously provide in vivo evidence that the archaeal KsgA-dependent 751 methylations of the 16S rRNA are completed at a late stage of the small ribosomal subunit 752 biogenesis. This result is in agreement with previous studies done in yeast and bacteria 84-86 . 753 the hyperthermophile P. furiosus, and a decrease amount of predicted rRNA 755 modifications in halophile H. volcanii in comparison to E. coli. These differential modification 756 patterns across archaea are in good agreement with previous studies and may reflect adaptation 757 to the environmental conditions that these extremophilic archaea encounter 49,87,88 . Unfortunately, 758 the exact nature of these modifications can not be unveiled yet. To facilitate their high-throughput 759 identification, future studies will require to develop and train algorithms improving the 760 identification confidence of diverse RNA modifications. 761 762 Benefits and limitations of Nanopore-based native RNA sequencing 763 Taken together, a key advantage of the native RNA-seq approach is that multiple features can be 764 addressed at once distinguishing the technique from the Illumina sequencing technology or 765 biochemical assays. ONT sequencing does not require large scale equipment and is a fast method. 766 Moreover, the method does not necessitate a reverse transcription step or PCR amplification 767 thereby avoiding biases introduced by these enzymes. Due to the limitations of the sequencing 768 read analysis platform, ONT sequencing does not accurately detect small RNAs yet. Additional 769 limitations of the native RNA-seq technique are currently (i) the high amount of input RNA 770 required (2-5 µg) to reach good coverage of the transcriptome without rRNA depletion, (ii) the 3' 771 bias during RNA sequencing (iii) limited throughput and (iv) limited possibilities for multiplexing. 772Although ONT sequencing has a comparably low sequencing accuracy, this did not pose a limitation 773 for our analysis. Due to the extraordinary read length and the sensitivity to base modifications, 774ONT-based native RNA-seq can provide valuable insights into (r)RNA processing, (r)RNA 775 modifications patterns and the transcription of large operons. Strikingly, ONT-based sequencing 776 is a bona fide single-molecule method and hence molecular heterogeneity in the transcriptome can 777 be analysed so that even minor RNA populations can be detected that are inevitably lost

Besides mature 16S rRNA and 23S rRNA, the remaining reads were classified as (1) a processing 860 variant that entails leading sequence-tRNA-trailing sequence, (2) probably fragmented full-length precursor rRNAs, 861 (3) leading sequence-tRNA, (4) leading sequence-tRNA-23S rRNA and (5) tRNA-23S rRNA (quantification shown in 862 Supplementary Fig. 13c). TABREF3.text: Sequencing yield and quality control of raw Nanopore reads 338 Native RNA sequencing was performed for three prokaryotic organisms: the bacterial model 339organism Escherichia coli, the halophilic archaeon Haloferax volcanii and the hyperthermophilic 340 archaeon Pyrococcus furiosus. In order to show that native RNA sequencing can be applied to a 341 wide variety of prokaryotic organisms, we specifically chose (i) organisms from the bacterial and 342 archaeal domain of life with P. furiosus and H. volcanii belonging to the Euryarchaeota, (ii) 343 organisms that are classified as mesophilic (E. coli, H. volcanii), hyperthermophilic (P. furiosus), or 344 halophilic organism (H. volcanii) and (iii) organisms that differ significantly in their GC-content (E. 345 coli: 50.8% 53 , H. volcanii: 65% 39 , P. furiosus: 40.8% 31 ).
